unit_learning_outcomes.description: Relate state-diagrams, truth tables, wave forms and logic equations as different representations of the same synchronous sequential machine.
Construct full logic circuits from individual integrated circuit components.
Design fast and efficient combinatorial logic circuits at the gate level.
Generate CMOS transistor diagrams from logic gate descriptions.
Apply Karnaugh-map and boolean algebra techniques to minimise combinatorial logic truth tables.

assessments.description: This is the first design assignment. You will take the knowledge about digital circuits presented so far and design a circuit to perform a given task.

There is a formal examination of the material covered in the pre-work, laboratory work, and lecture material presented during the unit. This is a hurdle assessment. You must pass the exam to be eligible to pass the unit. The exam is scheduled to last three hours.
This assignment is a design assignment. You must design and present a state machine to solve the project outline given. A rubric will be issued to indicate what is being looked for in the assignment.

Students are expected to actively participate in the learning activities with a developing level of independence. Before each practical session students may be required to complete preparatory work in a log book. During the practical sessions students must also complete their work and keep a log book of their work.

data.description: This unit aims to provide an introduction to the design and application of digital circuits and systems spanning full-custom CMOS building block circuits at the transistor level through to gate level design and hands-on integrated circuit based prototyping and testing in the laboratory. The unit also aims to provide the students with an understanding of and fluency in the combinational and sequential logic techniques used in the design of large-scale digital systems as well as preparing them for more advanced units on programmable logic design and digital systems.
data.title: Digital Circuits and Systems
